newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Motorola in bid for Romania GSM licence.
newsitem.headline: Motorola in bid for Romania GSM licence.

text.p: U.S. Telecoms group Motorola, Tele Danmark, Finland's Telenor and two Romanian communications firms have joined forces to bid for a GSM licence offered by Romania in a tender this month.

The new Zenith Mobil consortium, which includes Romania's private Radiotel and Rokura communications operators would try to secure one of the two lucrative GSM licenses in a tender on September 26, Kaare Birch, a spokesman for Zenith, said on Wednesday.
So far, 60 companies have bought the tender documents, communications ministry sources said.
Zenith is the second consortium officially to announce its participation in the tender.
Last month Italian telecoms group Stet Spa, French constructor Bouygues and Britain's Balli Group, backed by investment bank Goldman Sachs, said they had joined forces to bid for the work.
The consortium is negotiating with Romanian partners to boost its chances of winning the tender, it said.
Romania's communications ministry has already pushed back the closing date for the tender by two months to September 26 to give the applicants more time to consider their terms.
A cabinet reshuffle this week which saw the communication minister sacked would not affect the tender, the ministry said.

The tender requires companies to be able to cover at least 65 percent of Romania with the GSM system, to have solid operating experience and "serious" financial strength to back the costs of the project.

Implementing the licences is expected to cost some $1.0 billion. The telecoms ministry says the potential market for digital mobile phones is huge in Romania, with a population of 23 million people and relatively few landlines.
Romania is the last country in the region to set up a digital GSM system.
